message.content:
cs.IT, cs.ITP, cs.MM, cs.SI, cs.DS. 

The paper deals with information theory and communication, specifically the broadcast channel. Therefore, cs.IT (Information Theory) is the most likely sub-category. The paper also introduces a new tool based on an identity that relates the second derivative of the Shannon entropy of a discrete random variable to the corresponding Fisher information, which could fall under cs.ITP (Information Theory and Probability). The paper also mentions the use of extreme points and properties of auxiliary random variables, which could relate to optimization and mathematical programming, falling under cs.MM (Mathematical Programming) and cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms). Lastly, the paper discusses the computability and closedness of the region, which could relate to computational complexity and algorithms, falling under cs.SI (Social and Information Networks).
